<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>

<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_pool_allocate:
```c
void *
MHD_pool_allocate (struct MemoryPool *pool,
                   size_t size,
                   bool from_end)
{
  void *ret;
  size_t asize;

  mhd_assert (pool->end >= pool->pos);
  mhd_assert (pool->size >= pool->end - pool->pos);
  mhd_assert (pool->pos == ROUND_TO_ALIGN (pool->pos));
  asize = ROUND_TO_ALIGN_PLUS_RED_ZONE (size);
  if ( (0 == asize) && (0 != size) )
    return NULL; /* size too close to SIZE_MAX */
  if (asize > pool->end - pool->pos)
    return NULL;
  if (from_end)
  {
    ret = &pool->memory[pool->end - asize];
    pool->end -= asize;
  }
  else
  {
    ret = &pool->memory[pool->pos];
    pool->pos += asize;
  }
  _MHD_UNPOISON_MEMORY (ret, size);
  return ret;
}
```
</target_code>

The selected fragments are all places where buffer offsets, sizes, or a memory-touching macro are computed or applied and therefore need inspection to ensure any string.h (or similar) operations do not access beyond the referenced object bounds.
